bibl.title: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to William Crawford Gorgas, May 9, 1916

div1.p: Agramonte informs Gorgas that all his reports about the Yellow Fever Commission are completely accurate and can be proven, and that he believes he will never receive proper recognition for his contribution. [Courtesy of the National Archives and Records Administration]

div1.head: Letter from Aristides Agramonte to William Crawford Gorgas, May 9, 1916
div1.opener:
✓
Dr. Aristides Agramonte
Calle [unclear] (entre 15 y 17)
Habana-Cuba
May the ninth,
1916.
Brig. Gen. W. C. Gorgas, U. S. Army,
War Department,
Washington, D. C.
My dear General:
div1.p:
It was very nice of Col. Kean to have called your attent-
ion again to my work in connection with the Army Yellow-fever Commiss-
ion and I thank you also, for the interest you may take in the matter.

You no doubt refer to my article published in “The Scientific
Monthly”, December number, and not as you say, to the paper I read at
the late PanAmerican Congress. If it can be done, it would please me to
have it filed, as you suggest, in my personal records, in the War De-
partment.

In preparing that history of our work, I was very careful to verify
every statement by referring to the Military Orders, my notes, record-
books, etc. so that the date of every event can be certified to, if neces-
sary, as absolutely true, and you will notice that even the day of the
week is given, in some instances: I tried very hard to eliminate the
personal equation, in the wording as well as in the spirit of the paper,
that it might result a clear unbiased record of what took place and why.

It was originally written for a magazine less scientific than the
“Monthly” hence the style and the few, more or less, sentimental state-
ments it contains, which, of course, would have been entirely out of
place in a purely scientific exposition of our work.

There is not a single item there detailed, that cannot be proven
by documents easily obtainable at the War Department or that are in my
possession.

Now, I have no hopes of getting any special recognition either from
the American or the Cuban Governments. All governments are ungrateful
if not forgetful, and more praises, like prayers, are sung of the dead,
than notice taken of the living. Inasmuch as I remained and made my home
in Cuba, and an Cuban born, no doubt the Americans consider me an alien.
On the other hand, the Cuban big bugs believe generally, that our great
epoch-making demonstration took the wind out of Finlay's sails, that
his glory would have been greater, and would now appear greater, if no
mention were made of the U.S.Army Yellow fever Board, and I am de-
fending the importance of [unclear] its achievement at every opportunity,
even in my speech, at the foot of Finlay's statue, upon the occasion
of its unveiling.

Thus the matter stands, unmoved if not forgotten, and any change,
to my benefit, would come to me as a great surprise.

closer.salute:
Believe me, thankful,
and very cordially,
Yours,
